THE FEELING INDEX

Catalogued emotions, sorted by frequency. Each one measured, verified, wept over at least once.

Glitter-Induced Existential Dread

327.8 Hz
First documented: March 1977, suburban roller rink, Paramus NJ. Subject realized the sparkle was just plastic.

Gas Line Camaraderie

412.5 Hz
First documented: October 1973, Shell station, Reseda CA. Strangers bonded over shared scarcity. Friendship lasted one tank.

Bicentennial Guilt

198.2 Hz
First documented: July 4, 1976, nationwide. The fireworks were beautiful and something felt fraudulent about enjoying them.

Lava Lamp Hypnosis

88.4 Hz
First documented: 1969, dorm room, UC Berkeley. Subject stared for 47 minutes. Missed protest. Felt complicated about both.

Disco Ball Epiphany

741.9 Hz
First documented: New Year's Eve 1975, Studio 54. Light fragmented across 400 faces and each fragment was a separate person being alive at the same time.

Post-Watergate Trust Deficit

553.7 Hz
First documented: August 1974, everywhere simultaneously. The feeling that your television was also lying to you but about smaller things.

LOST DISCO TRACKS

"Crying on the Dance Floor (But Rhythmically)"

Emotional Classification: Choreographed Grief, 388 Hz
The bassline is a heartbeat that knows it's being monitored. The lyrics are just the word "fine" repeated 47 times over a string arrangement that sounds like a divorce filing scored for violins.

"My Platform Shoes Are Load-Bearing"

Emotional Classification: Structural Anxiety, 512 Hz
A four-on-the-floor meditation on the things we build ourselves taller to avoid seeing. The bridge is just breathing. The saxophone solo sounds like it's apologizing.

"The Fondue Is Getting Cold and So Am I"

Emotional Classification: Domestic Entropy, 267 Hz
Swiss cheese as metaphor. The holes are the parts of the relationship nobody talks about. Three minutes of wah pedal and then someone whispers "pass the bread" like it's a confession.

"Boogie Down to the Existential Void"

Emotional Classification: Nihilistic Euphoria, 777 Hz
The only disco track ever recorded in a minor key that still makes people dance. Bea played it at 0.75x speed and cried. I played it at 1.25x and laughed. The correct speed is somewhere we haven't found.

ENERGY CRISIS EMPATHY STATION

I remember the silence when the TV clicked off
My grandfather never threw anything away after that
We carpooled with strangers and it felt like family
The waiting was the worst part and also the best part
I still feel guilty leaving lights on
Scarcity taught me what enough means
